lines.value: mikhail alexandrovich bakunin 30 may 1814 - 1 july 1876 was a russian anarchist
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he was one of the early founders of anarchism
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: mikhail was born in the russian empire to a family of russian nobles he spent his youth as a junior officer in the russian army but resigned his commission in 1835
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he went to school in moscow to study philosophy and began to attend radical groups where he was greatly influenced by alexander herzen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: bakunin left russia in 1842 for dresden and eventually paris where he met george sand pierre joseph proudhon and karl marx he was eventually deported from france for speaking against russia's oppression of poland
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1849 he was apprehended in dresden for his participation in the czech rebellion of 1848
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he was turned over to russia where he was imprisoned in peter paul fortress in saint petersburg
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he remained there until 1857 when he was exiled to a work camp in siberia
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he escaped to japan the us and finally ended up in london for a short time then switzerland and italy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1868 bakunin joined the socialist international working men's association a federation of trades union and workers organizations
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a showdown with marx a key figure in the general council of the international ended with bakunin expelled for having a secret organisation within the international
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the far larger bakuninist international outlasted its small marxist rival which was isolated in new york
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: bakunin promoted the basic ideas of syndicalism and of anarchism
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: from 1870 to 1876 bakunin wrote some of his longer works such as statism and anarchy and god and the state
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the paris commune fitted many elements of bakunin's anarchist programme - self management mandates delegates a militia system with elected officers and decentralisation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: despite declining health bakunin also tried to join anarchists in bologna italy but was forced to return to switzerland in disguise where he settled in lugano
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he remained active in the worker's and peasant's movements of europe and was also a major influence on movements in egypt and latin america

lines.value: chromium is a chemical element
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: its symbol on the periodic table a list of all the elements is cr
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it always has 24 protons so its atomic number is 24
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: its mass number number of protons and neutrons is about 54
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most of the times it has 28 neutrons but different isotopes have more or fewer neutrons
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: as a metal it has 24 electrons
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: its ions have fewer electrons
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chromium is a shiny metal
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is reactive but it reacts with air to produce a very thin coating of chromium(iii oxide which prevents it from rusting any more
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chromium occurs in several oxidation states +2 +3 and +6 are most common
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it forms chemical compounds that are colorful
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are two main types of chromium ions which are found in chromium compounds
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one type of chromium ion cr 3+ , trivalent chromium ) is required by our body and by those of other animals
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if we do not get enough chromium certain parts of our body may not work properly
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: we get most of the chromium we need from our food we eat
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chromium is also put into vitamins to make sure that we get enough
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if we get too much of this type of chromium it can harm our body
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: another type of chromium cr 6+ chromate hexavalent chromium in the +6 oxidation state can cause cancer or make people sick even though most people do not get exposed to it much
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is found in places that make chromium metal which is why they need to be cleaned up when they close
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: hexavalent chromium can be destroyed by reacting it with reducing agents turning it into cr 3+ trivalent chromium
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they are strong oxidizing agents
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ;chromates the chromate ion is cro 4 2-
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chromates are generally yellow
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chromium occurs as chromite
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chromite is a mixture of iron(ii oxide and chromium(iii oxide
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: its chemical formula is fecr 2 o 4
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is heated with sodium carbonate to make sodium chromate iron(iii oxide and carbon dioxide
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the sodium chromate is reacted with sulfuric acid to produce sodium dichromate
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the sodium dichromate is reduced by carbon to chromium(iii oxide
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the chromium(iii oxide is reacted with aluminum to make chromium metal
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the chromates and dichromates are what make chromium production areas toxic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chromium is used in different metal products
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: stainless steel is the most common use

lines.value: it is also used in chrome plating where it makes things shiny and stops corrosion

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chromium metal is nontoxic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the island was discovered in 1502 by the portuguese admiral joao da nova and he named it santa helena after helena of constantinople
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the traditional date of this discovery was long thought to be 21 may but the results of an investigation into the discovery published in 2015 concluded this date is probably wrong the 3 may seeming to be historically more valid
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: another theory holds that the island found by de nova was actually tristan da cunha to the south and that saint helena was discovered by some of the ships under the command of estevao da gama on 30 july 1503

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they imported livestock fruit trees and vegetables and built a chapel and one or two houses

lines.value: though they formed no permanent settlement the island was for ships travelling from asia to europe an important place to stop to get food and water and frequently sick sailors were left on the island to recover
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after 1588 the island was visited also by dutch and english ships
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: by 1651 the dutch had mainly abandoned the island in favour of their colony at the cape of good hope

lines.value: a fort was completed and a number of houses were built

lines.value: dark matter is a type of matter thought to be responsible for much of the mass in the universe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the idea arose when astronomers found that the mass of large astronomical objects figured out from their gravitational effects was much greater than the mass figured out from the luminous matter they contain stars gas and dust
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: dark matter was first proposed by jan oort in 1932 as a reason for the spinning speeds of stars in the milky way
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: fritz zwicky in 1933 used dark matter to explain missing mass in the spinning speeds of galaxies in clusters
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: later many other observations have suggested that there is dark matter in the universe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the spinning speeds of galaxies gravitational lensing of background objects the temperature distribution of hot gas in galaxies and clusters of galaxies these are some of the examples that make scientists believe in dark matter
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: according to the planck mission team and based on the standard model of cosmology the total mass energy of the known universe contains 4.9% ordinary matter 26.8% dark matter and 68.3% dark energy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: thus dark matter is estimated to make up 84.5% of the total matter in the universe while dark energy plus dark matter make up 95.1% of the total stuff in the universe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because dark matter does not seem to give off or reflect light x rays or any other radiation the instruments that are used to find normal matter like hot gas stars planets and us can't find dark matter
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it seems that dark matter is not made of the same thing as the matter we see every day on earth
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the only way we can tell if dark matter is there is by how it affects things we can see by gravity
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 2006 a group of scientists claimed that they had found a way to find dark matter
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: since dark matter is supposedly very different from normal matter it is expected to act differently
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the scientists observed two far away galaxy clusters that had crashed into each other at high speed normal matter would have been scattered nearby after the collision while dark matter would not
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: by measuring gravity they were able to detect what looked like two clouds of dark matter with a cloud of normal matter hot gas in between them

lines.value: this behaviour has been observed when the animals completely consumed piecemeal bait

lines.value: an antigen is a protein expressed by a bacteria or virus that is recognized by the adaptive immune system as foreign which can stimulate the production of antibodies and combine specifically with them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: usually an antigen is a molecule perhaps on the cell surface of a bacterium or virus
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: antigens are always foreign and trigger an attack
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the system is normally tolerant of its own molecules which don't start an attack
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: autoimmune diseases are caused when this safeguard fails
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when an antigen is introduced into the body it causes the production of antibodies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: antigens include bacteria cells of transplanted organs plant pollen and toxins
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: antigens the production of antibodies they do not produce them directly
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the first time that a new antigen comes into contact with the body the response of the immune system will be a complete immune response
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: during this first response the antigen will cause antibodies to be made
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the next time the same antigen contacts the body a full scale immune response is not needed as the body already has a specific antibody available instantly for that antigen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this means that the body can begin fighting an infection much sooner for illnesses it has encountered before and takes more time to begin to fight an infection in new illnesses
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: vaccinations usually contain dead bacteria or antigen so the antibodies can familiarise themselves and kill it
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: bowing was originally a gesture a movement of the body which showed deep respect for someone

lines.value: this is why we still talk about bowing and scraping meaning that someone is trying very hard and hypocritically to be unnecessarily polite

lines.value: this kind of deep bow which is never used nowadays is sometimes called a reverence a word meaning deep respect

lines.value: minmi is a genus of small ankylosaurian dinosaur that lived during the lower cretaceous of australia about 119 to 113 million years ago
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a recent cladistic analysis suggests that minmi is the most basal known ankylosaur
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: that does not mean it was the ancestor of the group it is far too late for that
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it means its body is not specialized and is relatively unchanged from whatever was the ancestral group
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: two good specimens of minmi have been described including a mostly complete skeleton and additional fragments may belong to this genus
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the dinosaur grew to about 2 m 6.5 ft long holtz or 3 m long and weighed about 300 kilograms paul
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was roughly 1 m 3 ft tall to the top of the shoulder
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: minmi is classified in the ankylosauria but is too primitive basal to be included in either the ankylosauridae or nodosauridae
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: as with other ankylosaurians minmi was herbivorous unlike most herbivorous dinosaurs there is direct evidence of the diet of minmi gut contents are known from the well preserved nearly complete specimen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the gut contents consist of fragments of fibrous or vascular plant tissue fruiting bodies spherical seeds and tissue possibly from fern sporangia
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the most common remains are the fibrous or vascular fragments which have clean cut ends
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because of the small size of the fragments they are probably nibbled from plants or chopped in the mouth
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these small fragments may have come from twigs or stems but their size is more suggestive of vascular bundles in leaves
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the clean cuts and lack of gastroliths suggest that the animal relied on chewing to grind food
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the seeds 0.3 mm [0.01 in] across and fruiting bodies 4.5 mm [0.18 in] across were apparently swallowed whole
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when compared to gut contents and scat from modern herbivorous lizard emu and goose this shows minmi had a more sophisticated process for cutting up plant material
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it had bony protrusions on its head back abdomen legs and along the tail
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: several types of armour are known in place in minmi including small ossicles small keeled scutes on the body large scutes without keels on the snout large keeled scutes on the neck shoulders and possibly tail spike like scutes on the hips and a combination of ridged and keeled scutes and triangular plates on the tail
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there was one preserved ring of scutes around the neck
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the arrangement of armour is unclear on the tail although the triangular plates may have run on the sides of the tail with long scutes forming a row along the top of the tail
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however unlike other ankylosaurians minmi had horizontal plates of bones that ran along the sides of its vertebrae hence its species name m
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the arctic is the area around the earth's north pole
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the arctic includes parts of russia alaska canada greenland lapland and svalbard as well as the arctic ocean
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is an ocean but it is always covered with ice
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most scientists call the area north of the treeline arctic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: trees will not grow when the temperatures get too cold
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the forests of the continents stop when they get too far north or too high up a mountain
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: higher places are colder too the place where in the trees stop is called the tree line
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the area north of the treeline is not an empty ice field
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in fact the only large ice covered land is central greenland which is covered year round by a continental glacier
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the land of the arctic is around the edges of the arctic circle and is usually covered with tundra
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a tundra is a cold almost treeless plain covered with moss and grasslike plants called sedges
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: tundras do not get very much rain or snow
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however they are very wet in the summer time because three feet 1m or so below the surface the ground is always frozen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this permafrost is a layer of ice with the hardness of stone that keeps water from soaking into the earth beneath it
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: permafrost can be thousands of feet thick
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the summer the ground on top thaws out when the sun shines and the snow that did fall melts
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: but the melted snow cannot drain into the ground it just soaks the topsoil
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there is no place for the water to go except to form lakes and puddles on top of the ground until it freezes again or dries up.in the arctic during summer there are nights when the sun never sets
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is because during summer there the north pole points toward the sun
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: so sometimes people call it the land of the midnight sun
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the word comes from the greek word apktos meaning bear
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the north pole aims at the stars called the great bear and the little bear
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is why it is called the arctic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in some parts of the arctic the ground is covered with bright colored flowers during the short summer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these little plants have very short stems
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they must stay close to the ground because the earth is warmer than the biting winds that blow above it
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: even some rocks have plants growing on them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these rock plants are called lichens
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lichens will grow on the bare rocks
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: yellow reindeer moss is really a lichen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it grows slowly but often grows over six inches 15 cm tall
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is spongy and full of water
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this plant is the summer food for reindeer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: trees are rare on the tundra
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: only in the protected valleys or along the riverbanks are small trees able to grow
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: rivers come into the arctic from the warmer south
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the places along their banks are a little bit warmer than the rest of the tundra and trees can grow there
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: otherwise only a few clusters of bushes grow sparingly
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: berries are the only fruit that grows in the arctic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: each summer the ice and snow melt allowing the animals to find food and the plants to flower
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the moisture from the snow stays toward the top of the ground's surface
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: plant roots can use it for their growth
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: even so in many places the soil is too poor for plant's growth
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: less than half of the tundra has plants growing on it
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the polar bear is the world's largest meat eating land animal
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: polar bears are well adapted to hunt seals out on the ice
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they are excellent swimmers and the coldest water does not bother them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they wait by breathing holes if they pick up the scent of a seal
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they can also break through the ice at thin areas
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes they can sneak up on a sleeping seal
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they have a very strong sense of smell which they use to find prey out on the ice
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: polar bears get most of their food when there is pack ice
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they must eat and store fat before the ice is gone they cannot catch seals in open water
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after mating females dig themselves into a den of snow on land for the rest of the winter
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there they have their cubs usually twins
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: bears usually eat fish birds eggs seaweed and dead whales but they would rather have a meal of seal or walrus
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the arctic fox often trails the bears onto the ice to eat their leftover food
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the fox also eats rabbits lemmings and voles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the lemmings and voles are the rats and mice of the arctic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the lemmings have very short tails
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they live underground in summer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because the top soil freezes in the winter they cannot burrow underground then so they live under the snow during the colder months
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they eat plants and roots
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in a year with plenty of food millions of lemmings will be roaming the tundra
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the owls and foxes have more food than they can eat
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they will have more young in years when there are many lemmings
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however the tundra does not have enough food for millions of lemmings
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they rush across the tundra looking for food and are eaten by predators or starve to death
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some try to swim across lakes or rivers and drown
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the few that remain continue to have families
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: caribou and their relative the reindeer also live in the arctic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the caribou are now found mostly in north america and they are larger than the reindeer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: large herds feed on the grass and lichens
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when fall comes they move south to winter feeding grounds
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they dig through the snow with their sharp hoofs for food
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: their hollow fur creates a cushion of air around them that helps them to stay warm
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the spring they return north to the summer pastures where their calves are born
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: an hour or so after being born the calves are able to follow the herd toward the arctic ocean
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most of the world's reindeer live in europe and asia
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some of these reindeer are not wild
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they have been tamed by herdsmen who protect them from wolves and lead the migrations each spring and fall
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: also the musk ox which looks like a shaggy buffalo lives in the arctic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in summer many birds visit the arctic and most of them are water birds such as geese ducks swans loons and arctic terns
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: flying in for the summer they raise their young and return south for the winter
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the snowy owl and the ptarmigan stay all year
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the color of the snowy owl matches the snow
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the ptarmigan's summer plumage changes to white when it gets colder
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the smallest animals of the arctic are the flies and the mosquitoes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: thick swarms bite both men and animals in the summer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the reindeer try to escape the mosquitoes by running to higher pastures but the only real help comes with the snow and cold when the swarms die off for another season
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one of the surprises of the arctic is that many people live there
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some people have lived there for thousands of years
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: eskimo and lapp people lived in the arctic long before electric heaters snow mobiles and modern houses
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in an extremely northern part of europe there is a place called lapland
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is not a country but parts of four countries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the people who lived there are called lapps by outsiders
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they call themselves sami
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the lapps of these four countries lived there long before the countries of northway sweden finland and russia were created
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there were several kinds of lapp people
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some lived by the ocean and lived mostly on fish
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: another group lived along the warmer rivers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these people did a little farming hunting and fishing to live
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: but the best known of the lapp people were the nomads who raised reindeer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the lapps survived in their harsh homeland by domesticating the reindeer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the lapps were able to get everything they needed from the deer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they ate mostly meat milk and cheese
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: their clothes were made froom reindeer skins and wool
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: their tents were also made from deer skins
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they are known for the beautifully decorated woolen clothing they made
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the lapps protected the herds moving with them as they migrated from summer to winter pastures
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they used trained reindeer to pull sleds carrying their supplies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: during the winter the herds moved south of the treeline
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the lapps would live nearby in homes made of logs or sod
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the lapps were very careful not to waste anything they got from the reindeer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: milk was taken from the reindeer to drink or make cheese
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: meat was taken for food
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the blood was frozen in chunks and used for soup and pancakes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: knives and belt buckles were carved from the bones and antlers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the sinews were used as sewing thread
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cleaned out stomachs were used to carry milk or cheese
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: every part of a dead reindeer was used
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: winter clothing was made from layers of deer skin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the inside layer would be worn with the fur facing in toward the person's skin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the second layer was worn with the fur facing out
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: boots were also made of fur lined with grass that had been gathered during the short summer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: every evening the grass would be taken out and dried by the fire so it would be ready to use again the next day
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: thus a lapp could be warm and comfortable in even the coldest weather
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: today only a few of the lapp people still follow the herds
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: those few use modern tools on their ancient migration
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they use snowmobiles to herd the reindeer and rifles to kill the wolves that chase them

lines.value: the arctic region has many minerals that are important to people

lines.value: iron lead coal copper gold and are all mined in different parts of this cold land
lines.name: Simple English

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the oil in alaska for example is very important to the united states
lines.name: Simple English

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was discovered in 1968
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: plans were quickly made to build a pipeline to bring the oil to an ice free port so it could be shipped south
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: oil companies spent billions of dollars to build the trans alaska pipeline in the mid 1970s
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it had to be built above the ground in the northern section because of the permafrost
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the warm oil in the pipes could have melted the permafrost and caused the ground to sink
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: that would have broken the pipes and caused an oil spill
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the pipeline was completed in 1977
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it brings oil to the seaport of valdez on alaska's south coast
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: from there the oil is taken by huge tankers to refineries along the west coast of the united states

lines.value: fossil fuels are fuels that come from old life forms that decomposed over a long period of time

lines.value: the three most important fossil fuels are coal petroleum and natural gas
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: oil and gas are hydrocarbons molecules that have only hydrogen and carbon in them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: coal is mostly carbon
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these fuels are called fossil fuels because they are dug up from underground
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the oil sands in alberta about 1 billion cubic feet of natural gas was used per day in 2007 to heat the soil so the oil would come out of the earth

lines.value: most of the energy we use comes from fossil fuels as well
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most of the fuels people burn are fossil fuels
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a big use is to make electricity
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in power plants fossil fuels usually coal are burned to heat water into steam which pushes a fan like object called a turbine
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when the turbine spins around magnets inside the turbine make electricity
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: crude oil can be separated to make various fuels such as lpg gasoline kerosene jet fuel and diesel fuel

lines.value: these substances are made by fractional distillation in an oil refinery

lines.value: they are the main fuels in transportation

lines.value: that means that they are burned in order to move cars trucks ships airplanes trains and even spacecraft

lines.value: without them there wouldn't be much transport

lines.value: people also burn fossil fuels to heat their homes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they use coal less for this than they did long ago because it makes things dirty
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in many homes people burn natural gas in a stove for cooking
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: fossil fuels are widely used in construction
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most air pollution comes from burning fossil fuels
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this can be reduced by making the combustion process more efficient and by using various techniques to reduce the escape of harmful gases

lines.value: this pollution is responsible for causing the earth to get warmer called global warming
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they are also non renewable resources there is only a limited amount of coal gas and oil and it is not possible to make more

lines.value: eventually all the fossil fuels will be used
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some scientists think that coal will have run out by 2200 and oil by 2040

lines.value: renewable energy sources like biomass energy such as firewood are being used

lines.value: countries are also increasing the use of wind power tidal energy and solar energy to generate electricity

lines.value: chlorophyll is a chemical found in the chloroplasts of plants that allows the plant to absorb light
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: energy from the light is used in photosynthesis to make glucose
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this contains lots of stored energy which the plant needs to release
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it does this through respiration
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this energy is then used for lots of different things like growing or repairing damaged parts of the plant
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chlorophyll is also what gives the stem and leaf of the plant its green color
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chlorophyll is a green pigment found in almost all plants algae and cyanobacteria
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it absorbs light most strongly in the blue portion of the electromagnetic spectrum followed by the red portion
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however it is a poor absorber of green and near green portions of the spectrum hence the green color of chlorophyll containing tissues
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chlorophyll was first isolated in 1817
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chlorophyll is vital for photosynthesis which allows plants to obtain energy from light
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chlorophyll molecules are arranged in and around the membranes of chloroplasts
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it serves two main functions
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the function of most chlorophyll up to several hundred molecules per photosystem is to absorb light and transfer that light energy to reaction centres
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these pigments are named after the wavelength in nanometers of their redpeak absorption maximum
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these chlorophyll pigments can be separated in a simple paper chromatography experiment
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the function of the reaction center chlorophyll is to use the energy transferred to it from the other chlorophyll pigments to undergo a specific redox reaction
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in this reaction the chlorophyll gives an electron to an electron transport chain
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this reaction is how photosynthetic organisms such as plants produce o 2 gas and is the source for practically all the o 2 in earth's atmosphere
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: photosystem i typically works in series with photosystem ii
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the electron flow produced by the reaction center chlorophyll pigments is used to shuttle h + ions across the membrane setting up a chemiosmotic potential used mainly to produce atp chemical energy and those electrons ultimately reduce nadp + to nadph a universal reductant used to reduce co 2 into sugars as well as for other biosynthetic reductions
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a green sea slug elysia chlorotica has been found to use the chlorophyll it has eaten to perform photosynthesis for itself
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this process is known as kleptoplasty and no other animal has been found to have this ability
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it still is unclear exactly why plants have mostly evolved to be green
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: green plants reflect mostly green and near green light to viewers rather than absorbing it
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: other parts of the system of photosynthesis still allow green plants to use the green light spectrum e.g through a light trapping leaf structure carotenoids etc
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: green plants do not use a large part of the visible spectrum as efficiently as possible
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a black plant can absorb more radiation and this could be very useful notwitstandanding the problems of disposing of this extra heat e.g some plants must close their openings called stoma on hot days to avoid losing too much water
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: more precisely the question becomes why the only light absorbing molecule used for power in plants is green and not simply black
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the biologist john berman has offered the opinion that evolution is not an engineering process and so it is often subject to various limitations that an engineer or other designer is not
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: even if black leaves were better evolution's limitations can prevent species from climbing to the absolute highest peak on the fitness landscape
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: berman wrote that achieving pigments that work better than chlorophyll could be very difficult
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in fact all higher plants embryophytes are believed to have evolved from a common ancestor that is a sort of green algae - the idea being that chlorophyll has evolved only once common ancestor
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: shil dassarma a microbial geneticist at the university of maryland has pointed out that species of archaea do use another light absorbing molecule retinal to extract power from the green spectrum
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he described the view of some scientists that such green light absorbing archae once dominated the earth environment
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this could have left open a niche for green organisms which would absorb the other wavelengths of sunlight
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is just a possibility and berman wrote that scientists are still not convinced of any one explanation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chlorophyll is a chlorin pigment which is structurally similar to and produced through the same metabolic pathway as other porphyrin pigments such as haem
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at the center of the chlorin ring is a magnesium ion
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for the structures depicted in this article some of the ligands attached to the mg 2+ center are omitted for clarity
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the chlorin ring can have several different side chains usually including a long phytol chain
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are a few different forms that occur naturally but the most widely distributed form in terrestrial plants is chlorophyll a the general structure of chlorophyll a was worked out by hans fischer in 1940
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: by 1960 when most of the stereochemistry of chlorophyll a was known robert burns woodward published a total synthesis of the molecule
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1967 the last remaining stereochemical elucidation was completed by ian fleming and in 1990 woodward and co authors published an updated synthesis
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 2010 a near infrared light photosynthetic pigment called chlorophyll f might have been discovered in cyanobacteria and other oxygenic microorganisms that form stromatolites
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chlorophyll content meters measure the optical absorption of a leaf to estimate its chlorophyll content
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chlorophyll molecules absorb in the blue and red bands but not the green and infra red bands
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chlorophyll content meters measure the amount of absorption at the red band to estimate the amount of chlorophyll present in the leaf
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: to compensate for varying leaf thickness chlorophyll meters also measure absorption at the infrared band which is not significantly affected by chlorophyll
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the chlorophyll content of leaves can be non destructively measured using hand held battery powered meters
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the measurements made by these devices are simple quick and relatively inexpensive
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they now have large data storage capacity averaging and graphical displays
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: measurement of the absorption of light is complicated by the solvent used to extract it from plant material which affects the values obtained
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in angiosperms the last step in the synthesis of chlorophyll is light dependent
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: such plants are pale etiolated if grown in the darkness
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: non vascular plants and green algae have an additional light independent enzyme and grow green in the darkness instead
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chlorosis is a condition in which leaves produce insufficient chlorophyll turning them yellow
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chlorosis can be caused by a nutrient deficiency of ironcalled iron chlorosis or by a shortage of magnesium or nitrogen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: soil ph sometimes plays a role in nutrient caused chlorosis many plants are adapted to grow in soils with specific ph levels and their ability to absorb nutrients from the soil can be dependent on this
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: chlorosis can also be caused by pathogens including viruses bacteria and fungal infections or sap sucking insects
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ramadan sometimes spelled ramadhan is the ninth month of the islamic calendar during which muslims fast or do not eat or drink during the daytime
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the date for the start of ramadan is slightly different each year depending on the position of the moon
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: once ramadan starts muslims should not eat or drink between dawn and sunset
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this usually continues for thirty days but sometimes twenty nine days
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: fasting is supposed to teach muslims about patience and spiritual things
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is a time for muslims to think about how the poor and homeless suffer without lots of food it helps muslims to be more obedient and less greedy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: during ramadan muslims ask to be forgiven for their sins and they pray for help in stopping them from doing bad things
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: muslims believe ramadan is the month in which the first verses of the qur'an were revealed to the prophet muhammad
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: not everyone has to observe ramadan
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: children do not have to fast
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they should start when they reach the age of puberty so long as they are healthy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: people who are travelling long distances do not have to fast
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: pregnant women do not have to if they think it might harm their unborn baby
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes sportsmen do not observe the fast although there are disagreements about this
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for example the olympic games in 2012 fell in the middle of the holy month
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this made it very difficult for the sportsmen who could not eat or drink during daytime
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when the sun goes down and it gets dark the muslim people will start eating again this is called breaking the fast
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this meal is known as iftar
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are often big meals enjoyed together by lots of muslims
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: . sometimes markets open after iftar and stay open during the night
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ramadan is also the month when the quran was sent down into earth by an angel called jabrill gabriel
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ancient history is all the events we know about between the invention of writing and the start of the middle ages

lines.value: writing is one of the greatest inventions of the human species

lines.value: it was invented after the neolithic revolution in which people settled in small towns and started agriculture

lines.value: writing dates from about 3300 bc which is over 5000 years ago in the middle east

lines.value: the first people to use writing were the sumerians and the ancient egyptians
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: before writing the only things we have are the tools and monuments made by earlier people

lines.value: this is studied by archaeology rather than history
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the period of ancient history ends with the early middle ages
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: finding facts about ancient history is difficult because people wrote less in those times and much of what they did write has been lost
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there were very few copies made because there was no printing

lines.value: what people wrote they wrote by hand
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: more people could read and write in ancient rome than in other places but much of what they wrote is now lost
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: historians also look at things that were made and used in ancient history to learn more about it

lines.value: things like clay pots solid tools and metal weapons can stay the same during a long time

lines.value: things like paper wood and cloth can be easily broken burnt or damaged

lines.value: some ancient things found using archaeology are
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: primary sources are written by people who lived in ancient times
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: but people in ancient history may have believed different things from each other
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: strategy is a word which was first used by the military
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it comes from an ancient greek word for the general officer commanding all the armed forces of a state
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a strategy is a long term on what to do to achieve a certain
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when talking about the near future people often use the word tactics
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: military theorist carl von clausewitz said tactics is the art of using troops in battle strategy is the art of using battles to win the war
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: today the word strategy is in common use people might talk about business strategy for example
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the distinction between strategy and tactics applies to any planning which might be done against an enemy or opponent
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: strategy is what we broadly intend to do to reach our long term goal or
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: tactics is the detailed steps which are used as our progress is opposed by the opponent
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for this reason tactics are short scale and flexible
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: strategy on the other hand is changed as little as possible
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it may be that our goal simply cannot be reached
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in that case a search goes on for a new goal and a new or adjusted strategy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: often in war chess or business roughly the same tactics are still used to get to a different goal
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: negotiation is another area where the distinction between strategy and tactics is especially clear
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: giovanni gabrieli probably born venice date unknown about 1553-57 died venice 21 august 1612 was an italian organist and composer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he was very famous in his day and composed a great deal of church music motets and madrigals
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he lived at the end of the renaissance period and beginning of the baroque
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: about 1575 giovanni began working for orlando di lasso at the bavarian court as his uncle andres gabrieli had before him
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: little is known of his time in munich and he left in 1579 after the death of his patron duke albrecht
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there is no record of gabrieli's activities until 1584 when he'd returned to venice
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: that year he replaced organist claudio merulo at basilica di san marco church of venice's patron saint
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: due to merulo's resignation a contest was eventually held january 1 1585 to fill his post which gabrieli won having already occupied the position anyway
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: giovanni and his uncle who had raised him and taught him music worked together only a short time at the church before andres died in august 1585
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: giovanni held his post until he died in 1612
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: also in 1585 giovanni had been appointed as organist of scuola grande di san rocco where he composed ceremonial music
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: during all this he was also a music teacher
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: heinrich schutz was one of his students
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: giovanni is well known for being one of the first composers who specified volume markings and instrumentation in music
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: best known for his roles as gandalf in the 2001-2003 lord of the rings movie trilogy as sir leigh teabing in the da vinci code and as magneto in the x men series of movies

lines.value: he is openly gay and is a prominent activist for the rights of lgbt people

lines.value: sexual reproduction is how most animals and plants reproduce
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some protists and fungi also reproduce this way
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: organisms that reproduce sexually have two different sexes male and female
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: offspring is made by a sperm fertilising an ovum from the female.it involves both meiosis and mitosis and is very slow method of multiplication
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: different steps are involved in the process
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the cells of an animal or higher plant have two sets of chromosomes they are diploid
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when gametes sex cells are produced they have only one set of chromosomes they are haploid
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they have undergone a process of cell division called meiosis
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: two things happen during meiosis each of which makes the offspring more variable
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: that means they are different from the parents and from each other
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: assortment is when the double set of chromosomes becomes a single set in each gamete
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in each pair of chromosomes which one goes into a single gamete is random
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because the gene alleles on each chromosome are not always the same this means that there is genetic variation between gametes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this process was mendel's first law the law of segregation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because crossing over occurs during meiosis this increases the variety of the chromosomes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this makes recombination possible
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the consequence of assortment and crossing over makes it certain that no two offspring of the same mother and father are identical
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: identical twins are the exception being identical genetically because they developed from the same fertilised egg
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are advantages and disadvantages of sexual reproduction compared to asexual reproduction
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: rosa louise mccauley parks february 4 1913 - october 24 2005 was an african american civil rights activist
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she was called the mother of the modern day american civil rights movement and the mother of the freedom movement
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: parks is best known for what she did in her home town of montgomery alabama on december 1 1955
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: while she sat in a seat in the middle of the bus the bus driver told her to move to the back of the bus so a white passenger could take the seat in the front of the bus.during this time when there was no white seats for white people black people were told to get up out of their seat
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: parks refused to move
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she was a member of the local chapter of national association for the advancement of colored people naacp
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: like so many others she was tired of being treated as a lower class person because of the color of her skin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she was arrested
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this led to the montgomery bus boycott
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the boycott lasted 381 days
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this caused a change in the law
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after that black people could sit wherever they wanted to on the bus
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: her refusal to let others treat her differently was an important symbol in the campaign against racial segregation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: rosa parks was born rosa louise mccauley in tuskegee alabama on february 4 1913
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: her parents were james and leona mccauley
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she was mainly of african ancestry
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one of her great grandfathers was scots irish and came to charleston south carolina as an indentured servant
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: her father left home to find work when rosa was 2 years old
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: her mother taught school in another town
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: rosa and her brother sylvester were brought up by their grandparents
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: rosa started school in 1919 when she was 6 years old
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at that time schools were segregated
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there were black schools and white schools
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: later parks remembered how buses took white students to their school but black students had to walk to theirs i'd see the bus pass every day but to me that was a way of life we had no choice but to accept what was the custom
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the bus was among the first ways i realized there was a black world and a white world in 1924 she went to the montgomery industrial school for girls in montgomery alabama
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after 5 years she left school and went to work in a shirt factory
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she also took care of her grandmother
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on december 1 1955 parks got onto a city bus to go home after work
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she paid her 10c and sat down in the first row of seats behind the painted line on the floor which marked the black section
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after several stops more white passengers got on the bus
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the bus driver ordered parks and three other black people to give up their seats so the white people could sit down
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the other three moved to the back of the bus but parks slid over to the window
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she said she was following the law by sitting in the right section
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: later she said that when she was told to go to the back of the bus i thought of emmett till and i just couldn't go back till was a black 14-year-old who was lynched in mississippi about three months earlier the driver stopped the bus and called police
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: two police officers arrested parks and took her to jail for violating alabama's bus laws
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: her mother called upon edgar nixon to bail her out
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: nixon was the president of the local naacp chapter
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: nixon knew the danger parks was in and immediately arranged her bail
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the local naacp had been looking for a test case to challenge the bus segregation laws
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: parks was a respected working woman
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she was well spoken and her case would be a good way to challenge the law
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was decided that on december 5 a boycott of all the buses in montgomery would be held
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the word was spread throughout the black community of the intended bus boycott
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: black ministers told their congregations to support the boycott
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on monday december 5th rosa parks had to appear in court
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this was also the first day black riders would stay off the montgomery buses
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the streets of montgomery were filled with black people walking to work
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: black children walked to school
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: that same morning all montgomery buses were assigned two motorcycle policemen to guard against any black gangs intimidating riders
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there were no black gangs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the black community simply cooperated with the boycott
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the buses remained empty all day
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: white riders fearing trouble stayed off the buses as well
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in addition to the charge of violating the bus laws parks was also charged with disorderly conduct
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: her trial was quick only about 30 minutes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the court found her guilty of all charges and fined her $14
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the boycott continued
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: parks appealed her conviction
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: her attorney fred parks and others in the naacp brought an appeal named browder v gayle
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the appeals court ruled on june 19 1956 in favor of the black citizens of montgomery
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: but the city appealed the decision
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on september 13 1956 the supreme court of the united states upheld the lower court
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the bus boycott ended
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it had lasted 381 days
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: black citizens of montgomery could ride the buses and sit where they chose
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: rosa parks rode the bus again on december 21 1956
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this time it was an integrated bus
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ironically she had the same bus driver who had her arrested the year before
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in an interview parks said he didn't react pause and neither did i
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: rosa parks was a heroine of the black community
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: while she didn't do it alone her actions sparked a fire that led to great changes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after the montgomery bus boycott parks went through many difficulties
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she lost her job at the department store
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: her husband was forced to quit his job
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1957 parks and her husband left montgomery for hampton virginia to find work
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in hampton parks found a job as a hostess in an inn at hampton institute a historically black college
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: later parks and her husband moved to detroit michigan
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: parks continued to work as an activist
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for years she worked for united states congressman john conyers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after that she worked as an activist against apartheid in south africa
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she also opened a center in detroit that gave advice to black youth about careers and job opportunities
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1999 president bill clinton awarded parks a congressional gold medal
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is the united states highest honor most important award for civilians
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when he gave her the award president clinton said we must never ever when this ceremony is over forget about the power of people to stand in the fire for the cause of human dignity
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: parks died on october 24 2005 at her home in detroit
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on october 30 her casket lay in state in the united states capitol
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is a great honor for people in the united states
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cantonese is an asian language which comes from canton southern china

lines.value: often people use the word cantonese to refer to the guangzhou dialect hong kong dialect xiguan dialect wuzhou dialect and tanka dialect of yue
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however linguists prefer to keep the name cantonese for the yue dialect of guangzhou canton and hong kong
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: using this classification cantonese is the prestige dialect of yue
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cantonese is spoken by people in southern china hong kong macau malaysia and singapore as well as places with many overseas chinese who came from cantonese speaking parts of china such as melbourne
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is also the most common language of overseas chinese in southeast asia and north america
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is said that over 100000000 people speak cantonese
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is a tonal language with 6 kinds of tones
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: while cantonese is only the third most spoken dialect of chinese only behind mandarin and wu its official status in hong kong and macau make it widely known among other chinese dialects
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: even though cantonese is called a dialect of chinese cantonese is so different from mandarin the most spoken dialect of chinese that they are mutually unintelligible meaning that speakers of one language cannot understand the other language without learning it beforehand
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is said that cantonese is more closely related to classical chinese than mandarin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cantonese is from the sino tibetan family of languages

lines.value: in hong kong the official languages are english and chinese according to the basic law of hong kong
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the vagueness of listing chinese as the official language allows for the wide use of cantonese as it is called a dialect of chinese
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in hong kong many people speak cantonese instead of mandarin and some may even get offended if you speak mandarin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most schools in hong kong teach in cantonese rather than the language that they speak in mainland china in macau the majority speak cantonese and it is also the official language with the other being portuguese

lines.value: but here the people speak lots of other languages as it is popular with tourists because of its casinos

lines.value: orchestration in music can have two meanings it can mean the study of how to write music for an orchestra

lines.value: it can also mean the list of instruments that are used in a particular piece of music

lines.value: people who want to compose music for orchestras need to study orchestration
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they can do this by reading books about orchestration but also they can do this by studying orchestral scores and listening to orchestras in concerts or on cds
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: students at music colleges will also practise orchestration by taking piano music and arranging it for orchestra
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the word instrumentation means almost the same thing as orchestration
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: instrumentation means understanding each instrument and knowing about all the sounds they can make
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it can be about any music with instruments whereas orchestration refers to the orchestra from its beginnings in the 17th century to the present
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: orchestration is all about understanding how to write well for different instruments how to combine them so that they sound well together and balance well
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes composers leave the orchestration of their works to other people

lines.value: leonard bernstein is famous as the composer of west side story but although he composed all the notes he left it to other people to orchestrate

lines.value: the composer maurice ravel took a piano piece by modest mussorgsky who had died forty years earlier called pictures at an exhibition and arranged it for orchestra

lines.value: most people know this version rather than mussorgsky's piano version

lines.value: hector berlioz and nikolai rimsky korsakov are two famous composers who were particularly brilliant at writing for orchestra

lines.value: civil rights are rights that all people in a country have
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the civil rights of a country apply to all the citizens within its borders
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these rights are given by the laws of the country
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: civil rights are sometimes thought to be the same as natural rights
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in many countries civil rights include freedom of speech freedom of the press freedom of religion and freedom of assembly
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: civil rights also include the right to own property and the right to get and equal treatment from the government from other citizens and from private groups
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they may prevent against discrimination based on race sexual orientation gender gender identity and disability
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: civil rights are protected by law and custom
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the constitutions of many democracies have a bill of rights that describes the people's liberties and rights
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a well known example is the united states bill of rights
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a court of law decides if a person's civil rights have been
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the courts also decide the limits of civil rights so that people do not use their freedoms to take away the rights of other people

lines.value: :for other meanings of the word canon see canon
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a canon is a piece of voices or instrumental parts sing or play the same music starting at different times
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a round is a type of canon but in a round each voice when it finishes can start at the beginning again so that the piece can go round and round
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: perhaps the most well known canon is the pachelbel's canon written by johann pachelbel
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are different kinds of canon
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: canons can be described according to distances between the entries of the voices
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if the second voice starts one bar one measure after the first voice this is called a canon at the bar
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if it starts after only half a bar it is called a canon at the half bar
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is even possible to have very close canons e.g canon at the quaver eighth note
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: olivier messiaen wrote a 3 part canon at the quaver in his ' for violin and piano
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the pianist's right hand playing chords his left hand and the violinist are the three parts
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: canons can also be described according to the intervals between two voices
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if one voice starts on a c and the next voice starts the same tune on an f above this is a canon at the fourth because the interval distance from c to f is called a perfect fourth
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if the second voice has the tune upside down inversion this is called canon in inversion
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if the second voice has the tune at half the speed each note being twice as long this is a canon in augmentation or an augmented canon
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the opposite is a canon in diminution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: strict canon means a canon where each voice imitates the first voice exactly all the way through the piece
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if this does not happen i.e if it starts off as a canon but then becomes freer it is free canon
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a canon may start off sounding like a fugue but fugues have their own form and rules
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: canons were already popular in the 14th century when composers enjoyed writing music for several voices in which each voice has a share of melody this is called polyphonic music composers like guillaume de machaut wrote canonic music
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: his sanz cuer m'en vois is a three part canon in which each part has different words
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: probably the greatest writer of canons in the eighteenth century was johann sebastian bach
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many of his organ works have canons
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he wrote a famous set of canonic variations on vom himmel hoch da komm ich her which have several canons at different intervals and inversions
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he probably wrote this to show young composers how to write good canons
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: bach also wrote a work called the musical offering which has what he calls a canon per augmentationem contrario motu canon in augmentation and contrary motion i.e backwards as well as a canon per tonos
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this last one is a modulating canon which means that the tune changes key
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is hard to compose well so that it sounds good because when the first voice has just changed key the other one is still catching up in the other key
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: bach was a great master at writing canons and other very complicated musical forms
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after 1750 composers became less interested in writing music which was all polyphonic although many composers still showed an interest in counterpoint
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: haydn mozart and beethoven all wrote canons and even romantic composers like schumann and brahms showed an interest
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cesar franck wrote a canon for the fourth movement of his sonata for violin and piano
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is quite easy to hear this canon because the violin plays the tune an octave higher than the piano and the piano holds on to a long note every other bar while the violin catches up.in the 20th century composers such as schoenberg who wrote serial music were fond of canons
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: modern composers like pierre boulez have written rhythmic canons canons in which for example the rhythm of one part is the retrograde backwards version of another
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: april is the 4th month of the year and comes between march and may
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is one of four months to have 30 days
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: april always begins on the same day of week as july and additionally january in leap years
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: april always ends on the same day of the week as december
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: april's flowers are the sweet pea and daisy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: its birthstone is the diamond
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the meaning of the diamond is innocence
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: april comes between march and may making it the fourth month of the year
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it also comes first in the year out of the four months that have 30 days as june september and november are later in the year
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: april begins on the same day of the week as july every year and on the same day of the week as january in leap years
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: april ends on the same day of the week as december every year as each other's last days are exactly 35 weeks 245 days apart
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in common years april starts on the same day of the week as october of the previous year and in leap years may of the previous year
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in common years april finishes on the same day of the week as july of the previous year and in leap years february and october of the previous year
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in common years immediately after other common years april starts on the same day of the week as january of the previous year and in leap years and years immediately after that april finishes on the same day of the week as january of the previous year
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in years immediately before common years april starts on the same day of the week as september and december of the following year and in years immediately before leap years june of the following year
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in years immediately before common years april finishes on the same day of the week as september of the following year and in years immediately before leap years march and june of the following year
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: april is a spring month in the northern hemisphere and an autumn fall month in the southern hemisphere
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in each hemisphere it is the seasonal equivalent of october in the other
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is unclear as to where april got its name
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a common theory is that it comes from the latin word aperire meaning to open referring to flowers opening in spring
lines.name: Simple English
