lines.value: technetium is a chemical element
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it has the chemical symbol tc
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it has the atomic number 43
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the color of technetium is silvery grey
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is radioactive
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is a crystaline metal
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in chemistry it is placed in a group of metal elements named the transition metals
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the chemistry of technetium is somewhere between rhenium and manganese
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the isotope 99m tc is used in nuclear medicine

lines.value: it is used for many diagnostic tests

lines.value: a power network is a type of contact network where its members can tell other people what to do.it must be large enough to literally scare or force people to go along with its requests which makes them orders

lines.value: this typically requires thousands of people in constant touch with each other

lines.value: it is typically much larger than a social network but is not one since people can only call on each other for a small number of reasons and perhaps at specific times

lines.value: also not every member of the network has the same role or right to help

lines.value: a corporation may also be a power network if it relies on many power relations to maintain itself for instance the right to draw oil from the ground or dump waste without being held responsible for it.when a power network achieves some stable grasp of political power and daily working control of some important infrastructure it becomes a power structure

lines.value: she is recognized for saving mountain gorillas and starting a successful fund to help raise money for gorillas everywhere

lines.value: fossey loved animals since childhood but she was never allowed to have a pet

lines.value: a medical diagnosis is when a doctor finds out what is making someone sick
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes doctors can diagnose a sickness by asking the person questions and looking at the person's body
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes doctors do tests
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: tests can mean taking a small bit of blood urine or tissue which is sent to a hospital laboratory where it is tested
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: x rays are another form of test
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: tests are ways to see how the body is working
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when a diagnosis has been made the doctor may recommend treatment
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a vaccine is given by a doctor or nurse and makes a person less likely to get a disease
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it gives immunity to an infectious disease caused by a particular germ bacteria or virus
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for example the flu vaccine makes it less likely that a person will get the flu
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: vaccines are usually made from something that is alive or was alive
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: undead vaccines turn people into zombies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the word vaccine comes from the latin words vaccin-us from the word vacca meaning cow
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1796 edward jenner used cows infected with cowpox variolae vaccinae to protect people against smallpox
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the use of vaccines is called vaccination
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: edward jenner created the first vaccine in the 1770s
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at this time smallpox was a deadly disease
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jenner noticed that people who had already had cowpox a disease that is related to smallpox usually did not get smallpox
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he thought that getting cowpox protected people against smallpox
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: to test this idea jenner gave a boy cowpox
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: then he infected the boy with smallpox
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the boy did not get sick because he had already had cowpox
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jenner was right having cowpox protected people against smallpox
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because cowpox inoculation made fewer people sick than smallpox inoculation england made smallpox inoculation illegal in 1840
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1853 they made another law that said every child had to be vaccinated against smallpox using jenifer vaccine
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the 19th century louis pasteur made a rabies vaccine
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the 20th century scientists created vaccines to protect people against diphtheria measles mumps and rubella
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the 1950s jonas salk created the polio vaccine
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however vaccines still do not exist for many important diseases like malaria and hiv
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many countries have passed compulsory vaccination laws laws that require certain people to get vaccinated
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for example in many countries children have to be vaccinated against certain diseases in order to go to public school
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are many different types of vaccines
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one common type of vaccine is a live vaccine this type of vaccine contains a small amount of a live virus or bacteria
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: before the vaccine is given scientists weaken the virus or bacteria so it cannot make a person sick
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when a person gets a live vaccine their immune system learns to recognize and fight off that virus or bacteria
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: then if the person is exposed to the virus or bacteria in the future their immune system will already know how to fight it off
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: examples of live vaccines include vaccines for measles mumps and chickenpox
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: another common type of vaccine is an inactivated vaccine these vaccines contain dead viruses or bacteria
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these do not cause the immune system to react as strongly as live vaccines
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because of this people may need booster shots extra doses of the vaccine given at certain times so their immune system can learn how to fight off the infection
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: examples of inactivated vaccines include vaccines for pertussis whooping cough rabies and hepatitis b scientists can make some types of vaccines in a laboratory
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: vaccines do not guarantee complete protection from a disease
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in other words a person can get a disease that they were vaccinated against
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes this happens because the person's immune system did not respond to the vaccine it did not learn how to fight off the disease after the person got the vaccine
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this may happen because the person's immune system is already weak for example because of diabetes hiv infection old age or steroid use
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it may also happen because the person's immune system cannot make the particular b cells which make the antibodies that stick to the pathogen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some vaccines work better than others at protecting people from diseases
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are many reasons for this
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: since vaccines first existed there have been people who did not agree with the idea of using vaccines
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: around the world most scientists and doctors agree that the benefits of using vaccines are much greater than the risks
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the adverse effects from vaccines are rare
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: not vaccinating people is a much greater risk because vaccines prevent suffering and death from infectious diseases
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there have been controversies over using vaccines such as whether vaccines are safe the amount of research and whether it is morally right to force people to get vaccinated
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some religious groups do not allow uses of vaccines
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some political groups argue that people should be able to choose whether or not to get vaccinated
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they argue that laws requiring people to get vaccinated violate individual rights
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in response one study says vaccine refusal not only increases the individual risk of disease but also increases the risk for the whole community
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some parents choose not to follow the regular vaccine schedule for their children
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one study looked at parents of children ages six months to six years old
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it found that 13% of these parents reported following an alternative vaccination schedule
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however of these parents less than 1 out of every 5 reported refusing all vaccines
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most refused only certain vaccines and or delayed some vaccines until the child was older
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: parents who delay vaccines until their children are older are often concerned about their child's immune system being too young and weak to handle getting many vaccines at once
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one challenge in developing vaccines is economic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the diseases that most need vaccines today hiv malaria and tuberculosis exist mostly in poor countries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: companies that make vaccines would not profit much from developing vaccines for these diseases because many of the people who need them are too poor to pay for them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there would also be financial and other risks to these companies if they tried making new vaccines for these diseases
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: throughout history most vaccines have been developed by governments universities and non profit organizations
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many vaccines have been highly cost effective and good for public health
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in recent decades the number of vaccines given throughout the world has increased dramatically
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this increase particularly in the number of different vaccines given to children before they start school may be due to laws and support from governments
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: another obstacle to making new vaccines is that when a new vaccine is made the maker often files a patent on their vaccine
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these patents can keep the process used to make the vaccine secret
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: that can make it harder to make other vaccines using the same process
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: vaccines often contain other things besides the active vaccine the weakened or dead virus or bacteria
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for example vaccines may contain if no preservative is added to a vaccine harmful bacteria may grow in the vaccine
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for example in 1928 staphylococcus bacteria grew in a diphtheria vaccine that had no preservative in it
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: of 21 children who got that vaccine 12 died
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: animals are vaccinated to keep them from getting diseases and to keep them from infecting humans with diseases
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: pets as well as livestock are routinely vaccinated
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in some instances populations of wild animals may be vaccinated
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes wild animals are vaccinated by spreading vaccine laced food in a disease prone area
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this method has been used to try to control rabies in raccoons
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: where rabies occurs laws may require dogs to get rabies vaccinations
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: dogs can also be vaccinated against many other diseases including canine distemper canine parvovirus infectious canine hepatitis adenovirus 2 leptospirosis bordatella canine parainfluenza virus and lyme disease
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: epilepsy is a chronic condition of the brain
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is characterized by seizures that do not seem to have an obvious cause

lines.value: to the outside viewer these seizures show as episodes of heavy shaking
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: depending on the seizure the shaking may be short and difficult to detect or it may be longer

lines.value: there are many different forms of seizures and there are also many different forms of epilepsy

lines.value: in most cases drugs can make life easier for those suffering from it

lines.value: in very few cases which are difficult treat surgery may help

lines.value: today it is used to treat certain cases where drugs do not seem to help

lines.value: certain forms of the disease disappear after a time they do for example only occur in childhood

lines.value: the condition is very common about one percent of people worldwide 65 million have epilepsy

lines.value: epilepsy becomes more common as people age

lines.value: in the developed world of new cases occurs most frequently in infants and the elderly

lines.value: in the developing world this is in older children and young adults

lines.value: the condition has many forms but generally the following is true

lines.value: the condition is very common and has been studied a lot

lines.value: there are drugs for many forms of epilepsy that make life better for those affected

lines.value: doctors only say someone has epilepsy if that person has had at least two seizures for which the immediate cause cannot be seen

lines.value: in most cases epilepsy is caused by scars in the brain

lines.value: an estuary is where a river meets the sea
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there saltwater mixes with freshwater
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the river becomes wider and wider and flows slowly to the ocean
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: bays marshes swamps and inlets can all have estuaries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a view of an estuary from the air is usually an interesting sight many estuaries meander curve and bend to find their way to the sea
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: estuaries come in all sizes and shapes each according to its location and climate
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: where rivers meet the sea and fresh water mixes with salt water the mixture is called brackish water
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some estuaries are very large
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they may be large ocean bays that have more than one river flowing into them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for example chesapeake bay is a large estuary and several different rivers meet the atlantic ocean there
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: estuaries are usually filled with shallow waters and sunlight reaches all levels of the water
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: marsh grasses algae and other kinds of plants live in estuaries and provide food for a variety of fish crabs oysters and shrimp
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: estuaries are especially important since they act as nurseries for many different types of young fish and other animals before they head out toward the open ocean
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many sea birds also nest in estuaries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the united states government has a program to study and protect the natural environment in many different estuaries called the national estuarine research reserve system
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one reason that the natural environment in so many estuaries is in danger is because they are also good places for people to live and build cities
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: unfortunately many of world's largest cities are at or near estuaries

lines.value: genghis khan c
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: 1162 - august 18 1227 was one of the world's most powerful military leaders who joined with the mongol tribes and started the mongol empire
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he was a mongol emperor who was very successful in battle conquering many other peoples such as the jin dynasty
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he was a very strong and powerful emperor who occupied much of china and some surrounding countries of china
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: his children and his grandchildren started the largest empire in the world
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: genghis khan's grandson kublai khan was the first ever emperor of the yuan dynasty 1271-1368 in china
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: genghis khan's real name was temujin which means iron worker
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because of his military success people referred to him as genghis meaning universe ruler
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many people were killed by his armies and he gained a reputation as a brutal monster
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: genghis khan died in the liupan mountains in northwestern china in aug 1227 his burial site is unknown
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: temujin was related on his father's side to khabul khan ambaghai and qutula khan who had headed the mongol confederation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when the chinese jin dynasty switched support from the mongols to the tatars in 1161 they destroyed khabul khan
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: genghis's father yesugei leader of the borjigin and nephew to ambaghai and qutula khan emerged as the head of the ruling clan of the mongols but this position was contested by the rival tayichi'ud clan who descended directly from ambaghai
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when the tatars grew too powerful after 1161 the jin switched their support from the tatars to the keraits
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when yesugei was poisoned temujin who was only 13 became leader
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because of the lack of records there is very little information about the early life of temujin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the few sources that provide insight into this period often conflict
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: temujin was born in 1162 into an influential family who were part of a mongol tribe near burkhan khaldun mountain and the onon and kherlen rivers in modern day mongolia not far from the current capital ulaanbaatar
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the secret history of the mongols reports that temujin was born with a blood clot grasped in his fist a sign that he was destined to become a great leader
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he was the second oldest son of his father yesukhei a minor tribal chief of the kiyad and an ally of ong khan of the kerait tribe and the oldest son of his mother hoelun
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: according to the secret history temujin was named after a tatar chieftain whom his father had just captured
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the name also suggests that they may have been descended from a family of blacksmiths
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: yesukhei's clan was called borjigin bopknrnh and hoelun was from the olkhunut the sub lineage of the onggirat tribe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: like other tribes they were nomads
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because his father was a chieftain temujin was of a noble background
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after his death his third son ogodei succeeded him
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he had four queens and ogodei was born from his first wife
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: genghis was a great leader
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he lowered taxes and got rid of taxes for doctors teachers and priests
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he created the first international postal system
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: his empire was not known to be greedy with their spoils instead he would spread their wealth amongst the mongolians
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: temujin eradicated torture and held no prisoners
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in doing so he became respected
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he completely remade the feudal system to disregard people's ethnicity and instead based it on loyalty and their accomplishments
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he gave his people religious freedom unlike most empires that limited their people to one religion
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are no accurate portraits of genghis khan that exist today and any surviving depictions of him are considered to be artistic interpretations
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: persian historian rashid al din recorded in his chronicles that the legendary glittering ancestor of genghis was tall long bearded redhaired and green eyed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: rashid al din also described the first meeting of genghis and kublai khan when genghis was shocked to find that kublai had not inherited his red hair
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: also according to al din genghis's borjigid clan had a legend involving their origins it began as the result of an affair between alan ko and a stranger to her land a glittering man who happened to have red hair and bluish green eyes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: modern historian paul ratchnevsky has suggested in his genghis biography that the glittering man may have been from the kyrgyz people who historically displayed these same characteristics
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: controversies aside the closest depiction generally accepted by most historians is the portrait currently in the national palace museum in taipei taiwan see picture above
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: john winston ono lennon mbe born john winston lennon 9 october 1940 - 8 december 1980 was an english singer songwriter and artist who rose to worldwide fame as one of the founders of the rock band the beatles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after the beatles stopped making records in 1970 he lived in the united states with his wife yoko ono and continued his music career up until his death in 1980
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lennon started the beatles in his hometown of liverpool with paul mccartney and george harrison
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after ringo starr joined the band they started to be very successful
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: people were excited by their music and their live performances always pleased audiences
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: manager brian epstein and record producer george martin helped the beatles become the most popular act in entertainment
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lennon played the guitar and later learned to play the piano
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most of the songs the beatles recorded were written by lennon and mccartney
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: their songs were always credited as by lennon/mccartney on beatles records but in fact they usually wrote their songs on their own
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the two men often helped to make each other's songs better so they liked to share writing credit
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: famous songs written by lennon for the beatles are a hard day's night help strawberry fields forever a day in the life and many others
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the beatles grew apart as the members got older
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lennon divorced his first wife cynthia powell and married yoko ono while mccartney married linda eastman
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: each wife had different ideas and encouraged their husbands to depend less on each other
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: later some fans blamed yoko and linda for breaking the beatles up.lennon loved his wife so much that he added her surname ono to his own name since she became yoko ono lennon when she married him
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he had never liked his middle name winston given him by his mother after winston churchill and wanted to change it but was told he could not under british law
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he could add a new name though so he did that
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he never used the name winston again unless he had to for legal reasons such as when he travelled to america
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: otherwise he gave his full name as john ono lennon
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lennon recorded several albums and singles after the beatles disbanded
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the best known one was imagine
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he made many records with yoko ono
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on some records they called themselves the plastic ono band
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lennon and ono worked with different musician friends including ringo starr jim keltner klaus voormann harry nilsson eric clapton and elton john
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lennon's solo music was different from his beatles songs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he spoke more directly about his own feelings and sometimes used harsh language or loud sounds
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this upset a few fans who wished for more beatles music from him
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lennon and ono moved to the united states in 1971 and settled in new york city
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ono had a daughter kyoko chan cox from an earlier husband anthony cox a filmmaker who took her and disappeared
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was easier to look for kyoko and get the law's help to look if they stayed in america
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ono and lennon were also hurt emotionally by the way ono was treated by many people in england
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some insulted ono and asked lennon why he was with her
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on the other hand most of the people they met in america accepted them together
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lennon and ono were also campaigners for peace in the world
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they used lennon's famous name to talk to the media television radio and newspapers about their beliefs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lennon and ono were sometimes in trouble with people like politicians who did not like the things they said
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: president richard nixon's administration even tried to deport lennon because of his political views
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the two things lennon and ono wanted most were to live permanently in the united states and to have a child together
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: their lives were stressful in the early 1970s for several reasons
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there were the problems with immigrating to the united states and with the search for kyoko
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the public were also sometimes negative toward ono her music and her ideas
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the couple had several miscarriages caused partly by the stress
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lennon also had business problems because leaving the beatles was not as simple as quitting an ordinary job
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the beatles had signed many contracts
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they promised to do things in a certain way meet deadlines and work together to be paid as musicians and songwriters
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many business deals had to be finished or changed and new deals had to be made to continue their music careers apart
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this took time and meant making many hard decisions
